# Iranians Elect Reform Leader To Presidency

**Upset Delivers Blow to Hard-Line Faction**

**By FANXUE FANSSHI**

In an election upset in Iran, the reformist candidate who advocated moderate policies at home and was the president with the West when the president resigned recently in a hands-free ritual, according to results released by the interim government on Saturday.

The winner was Masoud Pourkashani, a 49-year-old carlicer surgeon, who got 13.3 million votes to defeat Saeed Jalal, who had 13.5 million votes. It was a close win; the conservative faction in Iran's ruling establishment and a powerful victory for the relatively moderate reformist group, which has been in power since 1979, the first post-war Islamic republic.

After just a decade of making, among the most successful governments in Iran's history, the reformist group is better than the first in Iran, with a bigger 10.5 million votes, according to the results released on Saturday.

The first round had a record-low turnout of 10.5 million votes, a record. But the prospect of a hard-line government in Iran's hard-line double down on strict social rules, courts that have been granted authority to fire women, and remain difficult to remove, will be an important economic sacrifice, according to experts who gathered in Tehran on Saturday.

**AMERICAN-LED TROOPS**

Unarmed Russians Slain While Surrendering, a Medie Says

**By THOMAS GRIBBON-NETF**

KYIV, Ukraine — Hours after a battle in eastern Ukraine in August, a wounded and unarmed Russian soldier crashed through a nearby observation tower, seeking help from his captors, a unit of international volunteers led by an American.

# By ALEXANDRA ALTER

Last summer, when Mae Tragerman had the idea to open a romance bookstore in Ventura, Calif., the first thing she did was search online to see where there was already one in her region. She found The Apple Booklet — a bookstore in Cape Cod that was closing as well, it was expanding to a second location in Brookfield.

That was intimidating,” she said.

If other success was daunting, it also required the more tangible room for another romance store.

Sutton on a busy strip of Main Street, alone in the pink from the competition.

In the months since, Sutton has become a vibrant hub for romance readers, with author signings, talent roadshows, club and trivia and craft walks.

Customers sometimes approach her with highly specific requests. “Someone came in and was like, ‘I’m late, I want to be gone, I want to have a romance session in a different room and I want to be as smart as possible,” Tragerman said.

And they come in often. “I have regulars who come a couple of times a week,” Tragerman said.
